There's a lot more hydrilla in this photo than what's in the bag. In fact, in Cayuga Lake behind me there are 27 acres of it, and that's not a good thing. Hydrilla is an invasive aquatic plant known to cause environmental, ecological and economic damage in communities from Canada to Texas. That's why we have to keep it from spreading in Cayuga and across the Finger Lakes and to do that we need the support of the EPA. I'm working with the Finger Lakes Institute to make it happen before the hydrilla spreads even more.

Unfortunately the President‚Äôs failure to name China a currency manipulator is symptomatic of a lack of real, tough action on trade against China. China steals our intellectual property, doesn‚Äôt let American companies compete in China, and has manipulated their currency causing the loss of millions of jobs. While they‚Äôre not manipulating their currency at the moment because it doesn‚Äôt suit their economic needs, make no mistake about it, as soon as the tide turns they will. When the President fails to label them a currency manipulator, he gives them a green light to steal our jobs and wealth time and time again.

As we head into the 100-day mark, Democrats are going to hold the President accountable for the promises he made to working-class voters. Watch my floor remarks LIVE:

That's why we unveiled our plan today to raise the minimum wage to $15 and restore dignity to the workplace for every American.

This is Emma. She‚Äôs 9 years old, from Berne, NY and is a superhero‚Äîcan‚Äôt you tell from her purple cape?  She visited recently to ask me to co-sponsor a bill called The Lymphedema Treatment Act, which I proudly did. This bill would help kids like Emma and others get insurance coverage for special, doctor-prescribed compression garments that help people with lymphedema manage their condition. She‚Äôs growing really quickly (like any 9-year-old should) and her insurance company is dragging their feet supplying new garments. The LTA would fix that‚Äîhere‚Äôs what she sent my healthcare staffer, Morgan: ‚ÄúHi Ms. Morgan! Do you remember me? it‚Äôs Emma (purple cape) and I met you in March with The Lymphedema Treatment Act meeting. I‚Äôm 9 now so mom is making me type my own email-im not that good. But this is very important. Do you know how much it means to me that Senator Schumer cosigned the LTA? It means everything!!! He has so many important things to do and since he cosigned it means he really cares. I bet you do too because you probably do a lot of his work. I think it‚Äôs important that I tell you both the biggest THANK YOU in the world. Right now my garments are too tight because since I‚Äôm 9 I grew a lot. Im waiting on insurance for my new ones because they‚Äôre not used to me growing so fast and they don‚Äôt want to pay for them. The LTA is going to help me stay healthy so I can just be a regular kid. So thank you 100 million times for cosigning and I hope you have a great day!  PS-can you tell Senator Schumer how much this means to me. You are both very nice people!  Thank you Ì†ΩÌ∏ä Emma 9, Berne NY‚Äù  You‚Äôre welcome, Emma‚ÄîI just want you to be a regular kid, too.  CC: @LymphaticNet #EmmasIncredibles

The Russia Sanctions Bill sends a strong message to President Putin, and any other foreign adversary who might try to undermine our democracy, that meddling in U.S. elections will not be tolerated, period. It also ensures that this administration, which has been far too soft on Russia, cannot unilaterally lift sanctions without Congressional approval.  The President signing the legislation into law today, although begrudgingly, was the right thing to do. It‚Äôs a critical response to Putin‚Äôs brazen attack on the cornerstone of our democracy ‚Äì our elections. The President's extended signing statement, however, demonstrates that Congress is going to need to keep a sharp eye on this Administration‚Äôs implementation of this critical law and any actions it takes with respect to Ukraine.   Democrats and Republicans worked well together to ensure that this bill arrived at the President‚Äôs desk with a veto-proof majority. This legislation shows its possible for the two parties to work together to rein in the President when he veers off track, and I hope it serves as a model for the future.

Big news! Binghamton Rumble Ponies will host the 2020 Eastern League All-Star Game! This win will bring baseball fans from far and wide to celebrate their love of the game, enjoy the city ‚Äì and maybe even have a Spiedie!

It doesn‚Äôt take Albert Einstein to understand why it is so important to begin the process of requiring sleep apnea testing for train operators. In the last 17 years, obstructive sleep apnea has been the probable cause of 10 highway and rail accidents investigated by the National Transportation Safety Board. It's time to test for sleep apnea on the federal level to ensure the safety of workers and passengers on our nation's rail and highways. That was exactly the plan, but this screening law has been abruptly cancelled for no good reason and it will put lives at risk. The feds need to put their national testing plan back on track.

Last night, President Trump threatened to shut down the government over funding for a border wall. If the President pursues this path, against the wishes of both Republicans and Democrats, as well as the majority of the American people, he will be heading towards a government shutdown which nobody will like and which won‚Äôt accomplish anything. In April, Democrats and Republicans came together to pass a strong, bipartisan appropriations bill that increased funding for our troops, scientific research, border security, and more. Putting aside the fact that Mexico was supposed to pay for the wall,  there‚Äôs even bipartisan agreement that a border wall doesn‚Äôt equal real border security; we need smart technology, drones, and modernized facilities to secure the border.   Working together, Republicans and Democrats in Congress can do our job and fund the government for FY2018. I‚Äôm sure the House and Senate will rise above the President‚Äôs threats of a government shutdown and send a bipartisan appropriations bill to his desk without a wall. The real answer isn‚Äôt a wall, it‚Äôs passing bipartisan, comprehensive immigration reform. The president might not be aware, but in our comprehensive immigration bill, we have invested $40 billion in real border security. We‚Äôll continue to fight for these principles to ensure our border is safe.

In the meeting earlier today, the President and Congressional leadership agreed to pass aid for Hurricane Harvey, an extension of the national debt limit, and a continuing resolution to fund the government both to December 15, all together. September 11th was one of those before-and-after moments. Nothing was the same since. We were awakened to a new manner of evil that had previously been beyond our imagination. But on this day, as we solemnly remember those who were taken from us that day, let us also remember what that day revealed about us.  ‚ÄúOn a normal day, we value heroism because it is uncommon,‚Äù wrote Nancy Gibbs of Time Magazine three days after the attack, ‚ÄúOn Sept. 11th, we valued heroism because it was everywhere.‚Äù  Firefighters and police and union workers searched, undaunted, through dust and smoke, through fire and ash, for citizens trapped in the rubble. Average Americans pulled the wounded to safety. Folks from coast to coast lined up for blood drives and pooled their money for donations.  This morning I came from the 9/11 memorial in New York City with victims' families just like these. Where once there were mighty towers now there are two deep scars in the Earth. But we remember. We rebuilt. We came back stronger.

I spoke earlier with the Governor of Puerto Rico about the significant damages after Hurricane Maria. I asked the Governor what he needed, and his requests were clear. U.S. Senate Democrats are calling on the President and the administration to deliver what they need and deliver it quickly. These are U.S. citizens that need help.   -First, Puerto Rico needs additional security presence of at least 1000-1500 people. They need US military disaster and humanitarian assistance to help maintain order and man food and fuel.  -Second, they need additional first responders, and all available resources to help restore communications on the island. -Third, they need at least 200 generators, additional fuel, and fuel trucks. -Fourth, they need hundreds of power workers to get the power back up and running.  -Lastly, FEMA and the Coast Guard need to get the Roosevelt Roads Naval Station, which is now also an airport completely back up and running, to help get supplies and personnel to the island. If these photos show anything, it's that the federal government needs to get these things, and they need to get these things done now.
